questions.text: Indication for this incision: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Open rhinoplasty

 

The image shows an incision along the columella and the nostrils, characteristic of an open rhinoplasty approach. In open rhinoplasty, this type of incision allows the surgeon to lift the skin over the nasal dorsum, providing direct visualization of the underlying bony and cartilaginous structures, including the alar cartilages and nasal bones. This approach is used for making precise adjustments to the shape of the external nose.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Caldwell luc: Caldwell-Luc surgery is a procedure primarily used for accessing the maxillary sinus. It involves making an incision in the gingivobuccal sulcus (inside the mouth) to enter the maxillary sinus through the anterior wall. This approach is not related to nasal dorsum access and does not involve incisions on the external nose.

 

 

Option B. Midfacial degloving: Midfacial degloving is a technique used for the removal of extensive nasopharyngeal tumors, such as juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibromas (JNA). It involves lifting the facial soft tissues, including the nasal mucosa, through incisions made intraorally. This method provides access to the nasal cavity and maxillary sinus but does not involve an incision like the one shown in the image.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The incision shown in the image is specific to open rhinoplasty, allowing direct access to the nasal structures for reshaping and reconstructive procedures.

questions.text:
Identify the cause(s) that result in non-scarring alopecia from the following options: (INICET NOV 2023)

 

  1. Alopecia areata
  2. Telogen effluvium
  3. Androgenic alopecia
  4. Frontal fibrosing alopecia
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2 and 3

 

Explanation:

 

Androgenic alopecia, alopecia areata, and telogen effluvium (1, 2 and 3) are responsible for non-scarring alopecia. On the other hand, frontal fibrosing alopecia falls under the category of primary cicatricial (scarring) alopecia.

 

 

  1. Alopecia areata 
    • It is an autoimmune condition that causes patchy hair loss.
    • The hair follicles are not destroyed and can regrow hair if the underlying inflammation is treated, thus it is considered non-scarring.
  2. Telogen effluvium 
    • It is a form of temporary hair loss that typically occurs after stress, a shock, or a traumatic event.
    • The hair loss is diffuse and does not involve scarring of the scalp.
  3. Androgenic alopecia
    • It is also known as male or female pattern baldness, is characterized by a progressive thinning of the hair in a typical pattern.
    • The condition is non-scarring as the hair follicles gradually produce thinner and shorter hairs but are not destroyed.
  4. FRONTAL FIBROSING ALOPECIA
    • Type of Hair Loss: Scarring alopecia primarily affecting the frontal hairline and eyebrows.
    • Predominantly Affects: Postmenopausal women.
    • Symptoms: Progressive hairline recession, eyebrow loss, and sometimes body hair loss.
    • Clinical Features:
      • Frontal Hairline Recession: Gradual and symmetrical.
      • Eyebrow Thinning: Outer third of eyebrows commonly affected.

 

 

  • Perifollicular Erythema: Redness around hair follicles.
  • Potential Causes: Autoimmune or hormonal factors may play a role.
  • Treatment:
    • Medical Approaches: Topical or systemic corticosteroids, anti-inflammatory medications.
    • Cosmetic Solutions: Wigs, eyebrow makeup, tattoos.
  • Prognosis: Hair loss is often permanent; early intervention may slow progression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Non-scarring alopecia, which allows for the possibility of hair regrowth, includes alopecia areata, telogen effluvium, and androgenic alopecia.
  • Frontal fibrosing alopecia is associated with scarring alopecia.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition Page no 32.24, 32.39-40, 86.17, 89.6, 89.7, 89.14, 89.17, 89.20, 89.24, 89.25, 89.46

choices.text: 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle
6 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle
4 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle
Midway between the anterior and posterior fontanelle

questions.text: You are applying a vacuum to deliver a baby in a patient with prolonged 2nd stage. The point at which the vacuum is applied is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle

 

The Ans. is 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle, which is the location known as the flexion point. The flexion point is critical in vacuum-assisted deliveries because it lies 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle on the baby's head. This point is chosen because pulling on this location causes flexion of the baby's head, facilitating the proper positioning for delivery. Flexion is crucial as it allows the smallest diameter of the baby's head to present, making the delivery process smoother and safer for both the mother and baby.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The flexion point, located 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle, is the optimal site for applying a vacuum during delivery to achieve the necessary head flexion.

questions.text: The average daily dietary nutrient intake level sufficient to meet the nutrient requirements of nearly all (97-98%) healthy individuals in a particular life stage and gender group is known as [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Recommended dietary allowance

 

Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA) is a level of intake corresponding to Mean + 2 Standard Deviation, which covers requirement of 97.5% of population. RDA is safe level of intake which is likely to be inadequate in not more than 2.5% population. RDA is often higher than the recommended minimum requirement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adequate intake: A value based on observed or experimentally determined approximations of nutrient intake by a group (or groups) of healthy people.

 

Option B. Dietary goals: are quantitative national targets for selected macronutrients and micronutrients aimed at preventing long-term chronic disease. They focus on population-level nutritional health.

 

Option C. The estimated average requirement (EAR): Average daily level of intake estimated to meet the requirements of 50% of healthy individual’s RDA is based on Estimated Average Requirement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA)

 

  • Definition: RDA is a level of intake corresponding to Mean + 2 Standard Deviation, which covers requirement of 97.5% of population
  • RDA is safe level of intake which is likely to be inadequate in not more than 2.5% population
  • RDA is decided by a panel of experts and is based on scientific research
  • RDA is often higher than the recommended minimum requirement: RDA includes both daily requirement and some additional requirement for periods of growth or illness
  • RDA is based on Estimated Average Requirement
  • RDA ‘safe level approach’ is not used for energy since excess energy intake is undesirable.
  • For energy: only mean or average requirement is defined as RDA.

questions.text: A person presented with neurological manifestations mimicking UMN (Upper Motor Neuron) palsy and sensory neuropathy. The patient was pale and investigations revealed anemia. The probable micronutrient deficiency is? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin B12

 

The neurological manifestations mimicking Upper Motor Neuron (UMN) palsy and sensory neuropathy, along with the presence of anemia, suggest a possible vitamin B12 deficiency. It can cause a type of anemia known as megaloblastic anemia, which can present with pale skin. Moreover, B12 deficiency can also lead to neurological symptoms such as UMN palsy and sensory neuropathy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin B9 (Folate): Folate deficiency can lead to anemia, but it is not typically associated with neurological manifestations resembling UMN palsy and sensory neuropathy.

 

Option C. Vitamin B3 (Niacin): Niacin deficiency can cause pellagra, which is characterized by dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. While it involves neurological symptoms, it doesn't typically mimic UMN palsy.

 

Option D. Vitamin B1 (Thiamine): Thiamine deficiency can cause beriberi, a condition that primarily affects the cardiovascular and nervous systems. However, it is not typically associated with symptoms mimicking UMN palsy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin B12 deficiency can lead to a variety of neurological symptoms, including UMN-like signs and sensory neuropathy, due to its essential role in nerve function. This deficiency can result from dietary inadequacy or malabsorption, leading to anemia and neurological complications. It's crucial to recognize the clinical presentation of vitamin B12 deficiency to provide appropriate treatment and prevent long-term neurological damage.

questions.text: Female on maize as a staple diet. History of diarrhea and lesion in the neck region. It is due to deficiency of: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Niacin

 

This is a typical picture of Niacin (Vitamin B3) deficiency causing pellagra. Pellagra is characterized by 4Ds i.e. diarrhoea, dermatitis (Casal’s Necklace) dementia and Death can also occur.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Zinc Deficiency is characterized by acrodermatitis (inflammation around mouth, nose, fingers, etc.), diarrhea, alopecia (loss of hair in discrete areas), ophthalmoplegia and hypogonadism.

 

Option C. Thiamine (B1) deficiency leads to Beri-Beri. CNS and CVS are affected in dry Beri-Beri and wet Beri-Beri respectively.

 

Option D. Pyridoxine deficiency cause anemia (microcytic, hypochromic) and seizures in infants.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Causes of pellagra

 

  1. Maize and Jowar in Diet: The major protein of Maize, “Zein” lacks tryptophan which is required for Niacin biosynthesis. 60 mg of tryptophan gives 1 mg of Niacin in the body. So, pellagra is more common when maize is the staple diet due to decreased synthesis of Niacin. Jowar has high content of leucine which inhibits tryptophan to Niacin conversion.
  2. Carcinoid syndrome: In this, Trp is mainly used for serotonin formation causes deficiency of trp for Niacin synthesis.
  3. Malabsorption
  4. Drugs like Isoniazid as isoniazid inhibits PLP (B6) formation which in turn is required for Niacin synthesis. Vitamin B2 is also required for Niacin synthesis, so, a deficiency either of B2 or B6 or both can cause pellagra.

questions.text: A 65-year-old chronic smoker came to the medicine outpatient department with complaints of upper chest discomfort and drooping of an eyelid. He also complained of pain radiating to the upper arm and a tingling sensation in the 4th and 5th digits of his left hand. The chest X-ray is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pancoast tumor

 

Pancoast tumors, also known as superior sulcus tumors, are a type of lung cancer located at the apex (top) of the lung. These tumors are particularly associated with several key clinical features and findings, especially in chronic smokers:

 

  1. Upper chest discomfort: This is a common symptom of a Pancoast tumor due to the tumor's location at the apex of the lung.
  2. Drooping of an eyelid (ptosis): This is part of Horner's syndrome, which occurs due to compression of the sympathetic nerves by the tumor. Horner's syndrome typically includes ptosis (drooping eyelid), miosis (constricted pupil), and anhidrosis (lack of sweating) on the affected side of the face.
  3. Pain radiating to the upper arm and tingling sensation: These symptoms suggest involvement of the brachial plexus, a network of nerves that supplies the arm and hand. Pancoast tumors often invade or compress these nerves, leading to referred pain and sensory disturbances in the arm and hand.
  4. Chest X-ray findings: The provided chest X-ray shows a mass at the apex of the lung, which is characteristic of a Pancoast tumor.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Upper lobe pneumonia: While upper lobe pneumonia can cause chest discomfort and possibly pain, it is not associated with Horner's syndrome or brachial plexus involvement. The X-ray findings would also typically show consolidation rather than a mass.

 

Option C. Superior vena cava obstruction: This condition can cause swelling and discoloration of the face, neck, and upper extremities due to impaired blood flow. However, it does not explain the specific nerve-related symptoms like Horner's syndrome or tingling in the digits.

 

Option D. Aspergilloma: Aspergillomas are fungal balls that develop in pre-existing lung cavities, usually in patients with a history of tuberculosis or other lung diseases. They do not typically present with the neurological symptoms seen in this case, nor do they commonly cause Horner's syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pancoast tumors, or superior sulcus tumors, are associated with upper chest discomfort, Horner's syndrome, and neurological symptoms in the arm due to their apical location and propensity to invade local structures such as the brachial plexus and sympathetic nerves.

questions.text: Where sharp waste can be disposed? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) White container

 

Sharp waste, which includes items like needles, scalpels, and other sharp objects that can puncture or cut, must be disposed of in containers specifically designed to prevent punctures and leaks. These containers are typically white, puncture-resistant, leak-proof, and tamper-proof. This ensures that sharp objects are safely contained to prevent injuries and the spread of infections.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: On performing a pulmonary function test, reduction in FEV1/FVC is characteristic of: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Obstructive disease

 

A reduction in the FEV1/FVC ratio (Forced Expiratory Volume in 1 second / Forced Vital Capacity) is characteristic of obstructive lung diseases. This ratio is a key indicator used to differentiate between obstructive and restrictive lung patterns on pulmonary function tests. In obstructive diseases, such as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), asthma, and bronchiectasis, there is a disproportionate reduction in FEV1 relative to FVC due to airflow limitation and air trapping.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Restrictive disease: In restrictive lung diseases, both FEV1 and FVC are reduced proportionally, often leading to a normal or even increased FEV1/FVC ratio. Restrictive diseases include conditions such as pulmonary fibrosis and other interstitial lung diseases.

 

Option C. Normal lung function: Normal lung function would typically show an FEV1/FVC ratio within the normal range, which is generally above 0.7 in healthy adults.

 

Option D. Interstitial lung disease: This condition is a type of restrictive lung disease where there is a reduction in lung volumes, but the FEV1/FVC ratio is typically normal or increased, not reduced.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • FEV1/FVC reduction implies obstruction.
  • FEV1/FVC Increased or normal – Restrictive lung disease
  • Decrease in Maximum Mid-expiratory flow (MMEF) i.e., FEV25%-75% - Small airway disease

questions.text: Kala-Azar is endemic in all these regions except: [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Assam

 

Kala-Azar, also known as visceral leishmaniasis, is a parasitic disease caused by the Leishmania donovani parasite. It is transmitted through the bite of infected sandflies.

 

Kala-Azar is not endemic in Assam. It is endemic in the following states in 54 districts:

 

  • Uttar Pradesh
  • West Bengal
  • Bihar
  • Jharkhand

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient who is a known case of COPD presented with acute exacerbation and in type 2 respiratory failure was admitted to the ICU. Which of the following statements is correct with regards to the initial management of this patient? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Non-Invasive PPV should be given

 

Non-Invasive Positive Pressure Ventilation (NIPPV) is often the initial treatment of choice for patients with COPD who present with an acute exacerbation and are in type 2 respiratory failure (characterized by hypercapnia and respiratory acidosis). NIPPV can improve gas exchange and reduce the work of breathing without the need for endotracheal intubation, thereby decreasing the risk of infection and other complications associated with invasive mechanical ventilation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Invasive Positive Pressure Ventilation (IPPV): This is generally reserved for patients who fail NIPPV or present with severe acidosis, hemodynamic instability, or decreased level of consciousness that precludes the use of NIPPV.

 

Option C. IV corticosteroids: While systemic corticosteroids are commonly used in the management of acute COPD exacerbations, the initial focus in a patient in respiratory failure should be on stabilizing the patient's breathing and gas exchange. Corticosteroids can be administered orally or intravenously, but this would not be the primary concern in the immediate management.

 

Note - Oral steroids (prednisolone) is given for 5-14 days in acute exacerbations.

 

Option D. Permissive hypercapnia: This is a strategy used in mechanical ventilation where slightly elevated levels of carbon dioxide (hypercapnia) are tolerated to avoid high ventilatory pressures that can lead to lung injury, however pH is maintained above 7.3. It is applicable during mechanical ventilation if it becomes necessary but is not an initial management step.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a COPD patient presenting with acute exacerbation and respiratory failure, non-invasive ventilation is the preferred initial management strategy to stabilize the patient's respiratory status, reducing the need for intubation and potentially improving clinical outcomes.

 

Reference - Harrison/Pulmonology/COPD/chapter 292

questions.text: Which of the following is most potent stimulators of aldosterone secretion? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hyperkalemia

 

Explanation

 

  • Hyperkalemia and activation of renin-angiotensin system are the most potent stimulators of aldosterone secretion.
  • Aldosterone, secreted by the zona glomerulosa cells of the adrenal cortex, is an important regulator of sodium reabsorption and potassium secretion by the renal tubules.
  • The primary site of aldosterone action is on the principal cells of the cortical collecting tubule.
  • Aldosterone increases sodium reabsorption while at the same time increasing potassium secretion is by stimulating the sodium-potassium ATPase pump on the basolateral side of the cortical collecting tubule membrane.
  • Aldosterone also increases the sodium permeability of the luminal side of the membrane.
  • Minimal levels of aldosterone not affect sodium balance but greatly impairs the regulation of renal potassium excretion and potassium concentration of the body fluids. Thus, aldosterone is even more important as a regulator of potassium concentration than it is for sodium concentration.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. АСТН: Incorrect as ACTH (Adrenocorticotropic hormone) has a minor role in aldosterone secretion compared to the renin-angiotensin system or serum potassium levels.

 

Option C. Hypernatremia: Incorrect because hypernatremia would typically suppress aldosterone secretion as the body would seek to excrete excess sodium.

 

Option D. Exogenous steroid: Incorrect as exogenous steroids, depending on their nature, usually suppress endogenous steroid hormone production including aldosterone through feedback mechanisms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyperkalemia is a potent stimulator of aldosterone secretion as aldosterone functions primarily to regulate potassium levels in the body, promoting its excretion through the kidneys while enhancing sodium reabsorption, crucial for maintaining electrolyte balance and blood pressure.

questions.text: A patient with history of alcoholism presented with right hypochondriac pain and fever. He had an episode of diarrhoea 1 week prior. USG abdomen reveals a liver abscess of around 25 cc in right lobe. What is the next step in management?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Medical management

 

  • This patient with USG revealing abscess in the liver most likely has an amebic liver abscess. Since next best is asked, medical management should be started first.

 

Amoebic liver abscess:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PAIR: PAIR (Puncture, Aspiration, Injection, Re-aspiration) is more commonly used for hydatid cysts and not the first-line treatment for amoebic liver abscesses.

 

Option B. Surgery: Surgical intervention is generally reserved for cases where there is no response to medical treatment or complications arise.

 

Option D. Percutaneous drainage: This can be considered if the abscess is large, at risk of rupture, or if there is no response to medical management. However, initial treatment should be medical management with antibiotics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For amoebic liver abscess, initial management should always begin with medical therapy using metronidazole, chloroquine, and diloxanide furoate.
  •  Drainage or aspiration is considered based on the size and risk of rupture of the abscess.

choices.text: Usually, terminates in awakening followed by confusion.
There may be neurological conditions associated.

questions.text: What is the false statement regarding somnambulism? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Person will have full consciousness.

 

Individuals who are sleepwalking typically act without conscious awareness and usually have no memory of the episode upon awakening.

 

Other Options:

 

Somnambulism, also known as sleepwalking, is a disorder of arousal from slow-wave sleep.

 

Option A. Disorder of sleep arousal: True. Sleepwalking arises from deep, non-REM (NREM) stage 4 sleep, making it a disorder of arousal.

 

Option C. Usually, terminates in awakening followed by confusion: True. When sleepwalkers are awakened, they are often disoriented and confused.

 

Option D. There may be neurological conditions associated: True. While many cases of somnambulism have no clear cause, certain neurological conditions can be associated with it.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Sleepwalking (somnambulism) is an arousal disorder originating from deep, non-REM stage 4 sleep. Individuals who sleepwalk typically act without conscious awareness and have no memory of the episode upon awakening. The person who is having sleep walking is difficult to awake.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 555.

questions.text: A person is exercising via performing different muscle movement, which of the following is correct regarding the muscle zone? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Band I decreases

 

Explanation: 

 

During muscle contraction, the I band decreases in size due to increased overlapping between actin and myosin filaments. "When the muscle is going to start contracting, the overlapping between the actin and myosin is going to increase. And because of that, the I band (only actin) is going to decrease because more actin will be overlapped by the myosin."

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. M-line decreases – Incorrect: The M line is the midline between two adjacent Z lines. "M line will never change" during muscle contraction. It remains constant as it's a structural component.

 

Option B. M-line & I band decreases - Incorrect: While I band does decrease, M line remains constant during contraction. Therefore, this combination is incorrect.

 

Option C. Band A decreases – Incorrect: A band represents the complete myosin filament length. "A band is a complete myosin that is nothing but whether it is overlapped by the actin or non-overlap does not matter. It will stay as it is." The A band length remains constant during contraction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During muscle contraction, while the M line and A band remain constant in length, the I band (containing only actin filaments) decreases in size due to increased actin-myosin overlap.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presented with cola colored urine and had a history of skin infection few days back. His creatinine value was initially 2.5 mg/dl but even after 3 weeks of treatment it increased to 4.5 mg/dl. Which of the following is a likely kidney biopsy finding on electron microscopy? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Subepithelial deposits

 

A child with skin infection followed by passage of cola colored urine is suggestive of post streptococcal glomerulonephritis. The worsening of creatinine from 2.5mg/dl to 4.5 mg/dl is suggestive of worsen of his condition in a short span of time. This prompts a diagnosis of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN).

 

Rapidly Progressive Glomerulonephritis (RPGN):

 

  • Pathology: RPGN is characterized by the presence of crescents in the glomeruli, which are formed by the proliferation of parietal epithelial cells and infiltration of monocytes and macrophages.
  • Clinical Features: Rapid deterioration of renal function, often following an infection such as streptococcal throat or skin infection.
  • Crescents can be seen on light microscopy in RPGN (especially crescentic PSGN).
  • But electron microscopy (EM) will still show subepithelial deposits, which is diagnostic of PSGN.
  • So, even though the clinical course is RPGN, the question asked what you see on EM - hence the correct answer is Subepithelial deposits
  • Type I: Anti-GBM disease (Goodpasture syndrome)
  • Type II: Immune complex-mediated (e.g., PSGN, lupus nephritis)
  • Type III: Pauci-immune (e.g., Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis, also known as Wegener’s)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subendothelial deposits: Seen in conditions like lupus nephritis and membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis, not typical for RPGN following PSGN.

 

Option C. Crescents in glomeruli: Suggest RPGN, but the specific hallmark of PSGN is subepithelial humps (crescents may appear if it evolves into RPGN, but not diagnostic)

 

Option D. Mesangial deposits: Commonly seen in IgA nephropathy and other mesangioproliferative glomerulonephritis, not specific for RPGN.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of crescents in the glomeruli on kidney biopsy is characteristic of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN), especially in a patient with worsening renal function following an episode of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis. However, crescents can be seen on light microscopy.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of palpitations, shortness of breath, and dizziness. The child has no significant past medical history. On examination, the heart rate is 220 beats per minute, blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg, and the child appears anxious but is otherwise stable. An ECG confirms the diagnosis of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT). What is the initial recommended dose of adenosine for this child? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 0.1 mg/kg

 

In the treatment of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT) in children, the initial recommended dose of adenosine is 0.1 mg/kg administered intravenously. This dose is given as a rapid IV push and is often followed by a saline flush to ensure that the drug reaches the heart quickly. The maximum initial dose should not exceed 6 mg. If the first dose is ineffective, a second dose can be administered at 0.2 mg/kg, with a maximum dose of 12 mg.

 

Adenosine works by transiently blocking the atrioventricular (AV) node, which helps to terminate the reentrant circuit responsible for PSVT. It is the first-line treatment for PSVT due to its quick onset of action and short half-life.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The initial recommended dose of adenosine for treating PSVT in children is 0.1 mg/kg, with a maximum dose of 6 mg. If the initial dose is ineffective, a higher dose of 0.2 mg/kg may be administered.

choices.text: Making a fist with forearm exercise
Tourniquet should be tied and released as soon as possible
Should be collected in sitting position & better to avoid prolonged immobilization
Sample should be analyzed within 15–30 min of collection

questions.text: Which of the following should be prevented when collecting a blood sample for serum calcium? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Making a fist with forearm exercise

 

Making a fist and performing forearm exercises during blood collection for calcium measurement should be prevented, as it can cause muscle ischemia and erroneously increase the calcium value in the sample. This is a practical consideration during blood collection when lab personnel often ask patients to make a fist and perform repetitive movements to better visualize veins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tourniquet should be tied and released as soon as possible: The tourniquet should be tied and released as soon as possible to avoid erroneously high calcium values. In some cases, for repeat calcium or PTH measurements, it's recommended to avoid tourniquet use altogether.

 

Option C. Should be collected in sitting position & better to avoid prolonged immobilization: Collecting samples in sitting position and avoiding prolonged immobilization is recommended, as standing can increase serum calcium levels. Prolonged sitting/immobilization can also affect values due to bone lysis.

 

Option D. Sample should be analyzed within 15–30 min of collection: Samples should ideally be analyzed within 15–30 minutes of collection. If delay is anticipated, the sample should be kept on ice (good for 2 hours) or centrifuged to obtain plasma/serum (stable at room temperature for 8 hours).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Making a fist and performing forearm exercises during blood collection for calcium measurement should be avoided, as it can falsely elevate calcium levels through muscle ischemia.

questions.text: A tuberculosis patient receiving anti-tubercular treatment complains of tingling and paresthesia in the lower limbs. He is not diabetic and drinks alcohol on occasion. Which of the following vitamins should be given to this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin B6

 

The patient's symptoms of tingling and paresthesia in the lower limbs, in the context of receiving anti-tubercular treatment, are suggestive of peripheral neuropathy. One of the mainstays of tuberculosis (TB) treatment includes the drug isoniazid, which is known to cause vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) deficiency. Supplementing with vitamin B6 can prevent or alleviate these symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin B12: While vitamin B12 deficiency can cause peripheral neuropathy, it is not typically associated with anti-tubercular therapy. Vitamin B12 deficiency is more commonly linked to conditions like pernicious anemia or dietary deficiencies.

 

Option C. Vitamin B2 (Riboflavin): Deficiency of vitamin B2 can lead to various symptoms, including skin disorders and anemia, but it is not specifically linked to the type of neuropathy seen in patients taking isoniazid for TB.

 

Option D. Vitamin B3 (Niacin): Deficiency of vitamin B3 leads to pellagra, characterized by dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia, and is not associated with the peripheral neuropathy observed in patients on isoniazid therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients receiving isoniazid as part of anti-tubercular therapy should be supplemented with vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) to prevent or treat peripheral neuropathy, a common side effect of this medication.

choices.text: β-2 microglobulin
Calcium levels
Serum creatinine

questions.text: Which of the following is a poor prognostic marker of multiple myeloma? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) β-2 microglobulin

 

β-2 microglobulin is a poor prognostic marker of multiple myeloma.

 

Multiple myeloma is a plasma cell neoplasm commonly associated with lytic bone lesions, hypercalcemia, renal failure, and acquired immune abnormalities.

 

  • CRAB criteria for MM
    • Hypercalcemia: serum calcium >11mg/dl
    • renal Insufficiency: serum creatinine >2 mg/dl or creatinine clearance <40 ml/min
    • Anemia: Hgb <10 g/dl
    • Lytic bone lesions

 

 

Poor prognostic factors for multiple myeloma:

 

  • Serum Beta 2-microglobulin - It is the single most powerful predictor
  • Deletion of 17 pITP53 sequences and the translocations t (14;16) and t(14;20)
  • Polyclonal serum Immunoglobulins
  • Elevated lactate dehydrogenase
  • High C-reactive protein
  • Increased plasma cell proliferative activity
  • High degree of bone marrow replacement
  • Presence of plasmablastic morphology
  • Elevated serum soluble receptor for IL6

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Calcium levels: Elevated calcium levels are part of the CRAB criteria and indicate disease activity, but are not as strong a prognostic marker as β-2 microglobulin.

 

Option C. Serum creatinine: Increased serum creatinine is also part of the CRAB criteria and indicates renal involvement, but it is not the single most powerful predictor.

 

Option D. Protein levels: Protein levels can be elevated due to monoclonal proteins produced by myeloma cells, but again, they are not as powerful a prognostic marker as β-2 microglobulin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

β-2 microglobulin is the single most powerful predictor of poor prognosis in multiple myeloma, reflecting the tumor burden and the rate of disease progression.

questions.text: Contact based isolation is employed for which of the following diseases? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) MRSA

 

Contact-based isolation precautions are specifically employed for managing patients who are infected with or are carriers of MRSA (methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus). MRSA is known for its ability to spread via direct contact with infected or colonized individuals, or indirectly through contact with contaminated surfaces and objects. This isolation strategy involves using personal protective equipment, such as gloves and gowns, when interacting with the patient, and applying rigorous hygiene practices to prevent the spread of the bacterium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diphtheria: While also a communicable disease, it primarily requires droplet-based isolation due to its transmission through respiratory droplets.

 

Option C. Mumps: Similar to diphtheria, mumps is spread through respiratory droplets and thus requires droplet precautions.

 

Option D. Asthma: Not an infectious disease; it is a chronic respiratory condition that does not require transmission-based precautions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The three categories of transmission-based precautions include:

 

  • Contact- based isolation is used for infections, diseases, or germs that are spread by touching the patient or items in the room. Examples include MRSA, VRE, diarrheal illnesses, open wounds, and RSV.
  • Droplet-based isolation is employed for diphtheria and mumps.
  • Airborne precautions are required to protect against conditions like measles, severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS), varicella (chickenpox), and Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

questions.text: At 28 weeks gestation, amniocentesis reveals AOD450 in Liley's Zone 3. What is the best line of management? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans B) Intrauterine transfusion

 

Liley's Zone 3 indicates severe fetal hemolysis requiring immediate intervention. When amniocentesis at 28 weeks reveals AOD450 (optical density difference at 450 nm) in Zone 3, this represents critical fetal hemolysis due to Rh isoimmunization. The spectrophotometric analysis of bilirubin in amniotic fluid directly predicts the severity of fetal hemolysis. With values in Zone 3, intrauterine transfusion is indicated to correct fetal anemia while allowing continued fetal development in utero.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immediate delivery: At 28 weeks, immediate delivery would expose the infant to significant prematurity risks. The fetus is not yet mature enough for delivery when intrauterine transfusion can correct the hemolysis while allowing continued intrauterine development.

 

Option C. Repeat amniocentesis after 1 week: Zone 3 indicates severe hemolysis requiring immediate intervention. Delaying treatment for a week would expose the fetus to continued severe hemolysis, potentially leading to hydrops fetalis or fetal death.

 

Option D. Plasmapheresis: Plasmapheresis is not indicated in the management of fetal hemolytic disease. This therapy doesn't directly address the fetal anemia, which is the immediate concern. The direct approach is to correct fetal anemia through intrauterine transfusion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Rh isoimmunization with severe fetal hemolysis (AOD450 in Liley's Zone 3) at 28 weeks, intrauterine transfusion is the optimal management to correct fetal anemia while allowing for continued fetal maturation in utero.

questions.text: Crying of a fetus in utero is called: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vagitus uterinus

 

Vagitus uterinus refers to the rare phenomenon of audible crying of a fetus while still in the uterus. This occurs when air enters the uterine cavity, allowing the fetus to initiate respiratory efforts and produce vocalization before delivery. This is an extremely rare occurrence and typically happens only under unusual circumstances where air has access to the intrauterine environment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vagitus vaginalis: This term describes crying of the infant when the head is in the vaginal canal but before complete delivery, not while still in the uterus.

 

Option C. Utero vaginalis: This is not a recognized medical term related to fetal vocalization or respiratory efforts.

 

Option D. None of the above: This is incorrect as vagitus uterinus is the proper medical term for intrauterine crying.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vagitus uterinus represents an extremely rare phenomenon requiring the unusual circumstance of air entering the uterine cavity, allowing the fetus to initiate respiratory efforts while still in utero.

choices.text: From the dorsal rami of C1

questions.text: Which nerve innervates the muscle marked in the given image? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Dorsal scapular nerve

 

The above image shows the levator scapulae muscle, which is innervated by the dorsal scapular nerve.

 

Dorsal scapular nerve arises from the brachial plexus, usually from the cervical nerve root C5. Muscles Supplied are Rhomboid major, Rhomboid minor and Levator scapulae.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Suprascapular nerve: It is derived from the upper trunk of the brachial plexus, which is formed by the union of the C5 and C6 nerve roots. Muscles Supplied are Supraspinatus and Infraspinatus.

 

Option C. From the dorsal rami of C1: It is a spinal nerve root. Muscles Supplied are Suboccipital muscles (rectus capitis posterior major, rectus capitis posterior minor, obliquus capitis superior, and obliquus capitis inferior).

 

Option D. Subscapular nerve: It Arises from the posterior cord of the brachial plexus and contains fibers from C5 and C6. Muscles Supplied are Subscapularis and teres major muscle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The appendicular group of back muscles and their innervations include: Superficial (appendicular) group of back muscles

choices.text: Do USG, don’t see the fetus gender and don’t tell the woman
Do USG, see the fetus gender and don’t tell the woman
Do USG, see the fetus gender and tell the woman

questions.text: G5P4 lady with 4 female children reports for the first time at 18 weeks POG. As per the PCPNDT Act and Beti Bachao Andolan, what will you do? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Do USG, don’t see the fetus gender and don’t tell the woman

 

In India, the Pre-Conception and Pre-Natal Diagnostic Techniques (PCPNDT) Act, 1994, strictly prohibits the determination of fetal sex to prevent female feticide. The act is a legal measure to curb the misuse of diagnostic techniques for sex determination, which could lead to gender-selective abortions. This law aligns with the Beti Bachao Beti Padhao initiative, which aims to save and educate the girl child.

 

In the given scenario, the woman is at 18 weeks of gestation. A USG (ultrasound) scan is recommended to assess fetal health and pregnancy progress but not to determine the fetus's gender. Neither the radiologist nor the obstetrician/gynecologist should attempt to determine or disclose the fetus's gender unless there is a valid legal or medical reason, which is rare and strictly controlled.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Don’t do the USG scan: This option is incorrect because USG is an important tool for monitoring fetal development and maternal health. Refusing to perform a USG scan without medical justification would be inappropriate and neglectful of standard prenatal care.

 

Option C. Do USG, see the fetus gender and don’t tell the woman:  This option is incorrect because, under the PCPNDT Act, healthcare professionals are prohibited from determining the gender of the fetus during a USG scan unless medically indicated. Viewing the fetus's gender without a valid reason is a violation of the law.

 

Option D.  Do USG, see the fetus gender and tell the woman: This option is incorrect and illegal as per the PCPNDT Act. Disclosing the gender of the fetus to the expectant mother or any other person is punishable by law, as it could lead to gender-based discrimination and sex-selective abortions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fetal sex determination and disclosure are illegal under the PCPNDT Act unless medically indicated. During routine prenatal care, USG should be performed without determining or revealing the fetus's gender.
